channel.title: JavaScript Nuggets
channel.author: JavaScript Nuggets
channel.description: Where little nuggets of javascript are posted, via twitter.

item.title: Tweet about spread and rest operators 1 of 7
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1116025934451224577. On topic: Tweet about spread and rest operators 1 of 7
item.content:encoded:
Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1116025934451224577.

Need a simple way to clone an object and add properties to it at the same time?

A shallow clone can be done like this #javascriptnuggets example. Here we clone `car` into `tesla` and add the `energy` property to it. #javascript #nodejs

Spread & Rest series 1/7 pic.twitter.com/d35aBQCsiN

— Shannon Duncan - üê¶ (@iamMrDuncan) April 10, 2019

item.title: Tweet about calling functions dynamically on an object
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1115666616367316992. On topic: Tweet about calling functions dynamically on an object
item.content:encoded:
Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1115666616367316992.

In this #javascriptnuggets example we show how to call a function dynamically that is stored in an object. Fun fact, this works on classes and prototype chains because they are just objects too!#javascript #nodejs pic.twitter.com/sainziWsj6

— Shannon Duncan - üê¶ (@iamMrDuncan) April 9, 2019

item.title: Tweet about objects as references vs objects as values
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1113193040250798081. On topic: Tweet about objects as references vs objects as values
item.content:encoded:
Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1113193040250798081.

When you copy an object, how you copy it matters. In the attached nugget you can see that if you are not expecting it, you may end up with changing values you didn’t mean to.#javascript #javascriptnuggets

More info and answers in the twitter thread below üëá pic.twitter.com/OiEZs1IoS8

— Shannon Duncan - üê¶ (@iamMrDuncan) April 2, 2019

item.title: Tweet about performance of queues in JavaScript with LinkedLists vs Arrays
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1112782248619720705. On topic: Tweet about performance of queues in JavaScript with LinkedLists vs Arrays
item.content:encoded:
Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1112782248619720705.

So when you create a queue for storing items to be processed in order of first in first out. How do you normally do it? Like below? That’s not the best and most efficient way.#javascript #algorithms

Lets talk about it in todays #javascriptnuggets in the thread below üëá pic.twitter.com/lFY5yYmhUc

— Shannon Duncan - üê¶ (@iamMrDuncan) April 1, 2019

An interesting thing that happens when using JSON and storing two different number types within the same shape of JSON.#javascript #nodejs #javascriptnuggets

More information in the thread below üëá pic.twitter.com/ghV9Js3OmP

item.title: Tweet about creating empty pure objects.
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1111675401980571648. On topic: Tweet about creating empty pure objects.
item.content:encoded:
Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1111675401980571648.

Did you know that when you create an object in #JavaScript using only `{}` that you have more than just an empty object?

Use the following #javascriptNugget, and read more in the tweet thread below üëá pic.twitter.com/YW5KKL6yLx

— Shannon Duncan - üê¶ (@iamMrDuncan) March 29, 2019

item.title: Tweet about creating an immutable constant
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1111430090846461953. On topic: Tweet about creating an immutable constant
item.content:encoded:
Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1111430090846461953.

Ever noticed that JavaScript const doesn't work like you think it should for objects? Well thats a deep rabbit hole, and heres a quick way to make a real constant object using Object.freeze. pic.twitter.com/k85ZylZGIj

— Shannon Duncan - üê¶ (@iamMrDuncan) March 29, 2019

item.title: Tweet about how to log to both the console and a file
item.author: Shannon Duncan
item.description: Todays javascript nugget can be found at the following link: https://twitter.com/iamMrDuncan/status/1108146983313788928. On topic: Tweet about how to log to both the console and a file
item.content:encoded:

When I want to write to both the console and a log file in #nodejs, this is what my captains.log is for üòâü§™. Simple. Easy to read. And works good for small use cases. Stardate 72679. pic.twitter.com/YMaqMoS93U
